channel.title: @hyperdbg - Telegram group archive
channel.description: Public archive of HyperDbg Telegram messages.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:36:19+00:00 (#1831)
item.description: Yeah, and also please consider this: In HyperDbg, we won't ignore the interrupts. We just save them somewhere in the memory and once the guest continues (we config VMCS to VM-exit on Interrupt Window Exiting events). So, after we continue HyperDbg from the 'i' command, it immediately re-injects the previous interrupts. Thus, a context-switch will happen right after continuing the core from an instrumented step-in.

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:33:24+00:00 (#1830)
item.description: only if is needed i use another with more cores

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:33:01+00:00 (#1829)
item.description: to avoid this

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:32:56+00:00 (#1828)
item.description: for this reason my start vm has only 1 procesor 1 core

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:32:20+00:00 (#1827)
item.description: yeah, agree. It's really hard to handle multi cores with different TLBs, EPTPs, CR3s, etc.

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:32:20+00:00 (#1826)
item.description: you are tracing and a breakpoint is triggered by another core and jumps to its location

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:31:35+00:00 (#1825)
item.description: in windbg using more than1 procesor 1 core drives you crazy when you are tracing or put breakpoints in kernel

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:30:03+00:00 (#1824)
item.description: I mean once HyperDbg continues the system (e.g, pressing 'g', or 't') then all other processes might (and will) get the chance to run in the system.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:27:55+00:00 (#1823)
item.description: I didn't get the point. Why do you use one core?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:26:38+00:00 (#1822)
item.description:
The details of the implementation is described here: https://research.hyperdbg.org/assets/documents/kernel-debugger-design-1st-edition.pdf
it might help knowing about some of the technical difficulties regarding this 'instrumentation step-in'.

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:25:54+00:00 (#1821)
item.description: only if needed i change to other vm with more procesor cores

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:25:20+00:00 (#1820)
item.description: for this reason my 1 procesor 1 core scenario by default is the best to start

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:24:58+00:00 (#1819)
item.description: yes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:24:41+00:00 (#1818)
item.description: It breaks the system.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:24:33+00:00 (#1817)
item.description: Based on the implementation, we masked the external interrupts to make this instrumentation step-in possible. No, what happens if a SYSCALL execute in the state when interrupts are masked?

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:23:27+00:00 (#1816)
item.description: it can be problematic

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:23:21+00:00 (#1815)
item.description: Imagine this scenario, you want to step-over a function that tries to write into a file.

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:23:15+00:00 (#1814)
item.description: yes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:22:38+00:00 (#1813)
item.description: You got it right but the thing is, it's technically impossible to implement a guaranteed step-over. Because we're not sure what a function wants to do.

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:20:21+00:00 (#1812)
item.description: but the starting point is 1 procesor and 1 core

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:20:03+00:00 (#1811)
item.description: if i need more cores i change to another vm

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:19:35+00:00 (#1810)
item.description: for this reason i have a one only processor vm with 1 only core to work

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:18:54+00:00 (#1809)
item.description: to step over without all the cores disturbing

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:18:29+00:00 (#1808)
item.description: the p command does not have the option like t (the i alternative)

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:10:18+00:00 (#1805)
item.description: very difficult

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:07:44+00:00 (#1804)
item.description: Still, we could use Windows APIs to notify us about the entrypoint, but that's not the case. We need to have an API (Debug) independent starting mechanism in HyperDbg.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:06:02+00:00 (#1803)
item.description: I could fix it by using MBEC (mode based execution controls), but MBEC is quite a new feature in Intel processors. Thus, if I implement it like this, we won't support the '.start' command on Skylake (6 gen Intel) and older processors anymore.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:04:24+00:00 (#1801)
item.description: And regular OS page table bits are also not usable. Because the entrypoint will be accessed several time by some functions in ntdll.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:03:40+00:00 (#1800)
item.description: For some unknown reasons, Debug Registers (which work with Virtual Addresses) won't work either.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:02:53+00:00 (#1799)
item.description: Sure we could intercept the page-fault, but there is no PFN (page frame number) available in the #PF handler. Thus, the physical address is unknown and we could not use EPT to intercept it.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:01:37+00:00 (#1798)
item.description: The problem here is, once the system wants to execute the target entrypoint, the address is not available on the RAM. Thus, it has to throw a #PF page-fault and brings the page in.

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:01:06+00:00 (#1797)
item.description: and if it starts in TLS code

item.title: @ricnar on 2023-07-03 12:00:20+00:00 (#1796)
item.description: yes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 12:00:03+00:00 (#1795)
item.description: I mean repeatedly testing it.

item.description: Yeah, it works for me too. But I think if you keep testing it and running it, it might fail at some points.

item.description: I test tens of variants, intercepting #PF page-faults, setting EPT changed breakpoints on read/write. Setting regular OS paging bits. All of them failed.

item.description: yeah, there isn't any bug in HyperDbg. Being HyperDbg and having bugs is a contradiction itself. How could a debugger have a bug? Not possible. 🙂😅😁

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 09:36:16+00:00 (#1740)
item.description: As long as that ini file is there, HyperDbg uses that file. But if you remove that file (recompile & clean everything), then you should set it again.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2023-07-03 09:35:27+00:00 (#1737)
item.description: What do you mean? Once you set the symbol path, one file 'config.ini' should be created there beside the exe file.
